text: hi everyone anthony fantano here
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a chilled out review of the new
lycus album tempest these guys are a
metal outfit from the west coast they've
been around for several years but this
is their first big studio recorded
commercial full-length release the band
actually features an ex-member of the
group death heaven for those of you who
are huge into the record sunbather you
might want to check this album out as
well but it's not as if lycus or
tempest have that much bearing in the
experimental black metal or progressive
black metal black gays world still i
would say this record is a forward
thinking and very melodic and engaging
approach to the style of metal that this
band does play very slow
dirge like funeral doom metal metal
songs in this style feature tempos that
that move like the seasons monolithic
riffs that have an epic sound and
melodies that are incredibly mournful
and just have this strong sense of
sadness pretty much the styles defining
characteristics since the 90s when it
was molded by bands like theragathon and
funeral as well as esoteric a recent
band to catch a lot of attention playing
in this style has been ahab if you count
about six years ago as being recent
leica seems really conscious of this
genre's past but they want to keep
things interesting and and modern as
well as slow as this banned songs are
they add a lot of detail and and
progressions into the mix really
justifying the long lengths of the three
tracks here that are 9 11 and 20 minutes
they're just endlessly flowing melodies
throughout this lp a lot of them
executed by guitar leads sometimes
they're layered and harmonized in a
beautiful way tons of dramatic drum
fills and expressive guitar chords that
remind me of chord progressions that
i've heard on records like wolves in the
throne rooms to hunters or even that new
pallbearer record plus there are plenty
of peaks and valleys as these songs go
from beginning to end i dig the vocals
on this lp2 i wish there was a bit more
variety to them but just these monstrous
growls front pretty much every track
here that combined together with the
melody and just the sloth-like pace of
these songs i feel like i'm listening to
slowed down death metal power ballads
it's skulls and rock horns and corpses
and lighters in a way the music on this
lp is is just reflective of the paolo
gerardi oil painting that is slapped on
the cover it's just a really gruesome
display but it's the very melodic
coloring that gives these grim edges
flavor and depth and emotion there isn't
much on tempus that i would say is
catchy you're not really going to commit
much of this album to memory if you're
just giving it a cursory listen i would
say that's because this is more of an
album to just get
lost in and that's easy to do with just
how huge the sound lycus presents is on
top of the fact that the melodies on
this lp on these songs are constantly
shifting but they occur and just sort of
blossom at this very slow pace that
keeps them engaging but also makes them
sort of easy to take in even though
these songs are just constantly winding
there's details and and i guess variety
on these tracks but but not so much it's
dizzying even as the band layers on more
guitars throws in more background vocals
or even puts strings which they do at
several phases in these songs the
opening track on this lp coma burn opens
up with these minor toned harmonious
chords that are just loud distorted
blaring they just have this massive
sound there's a ton of bass in this mix
and even though it's incredibly heavy
it's not like this pummeling or
overwhelming heaviness really it's more
of an enveloping heaviness it's just
vast it's open the more i listen to this
record the more it feels like i'm
sinking down into a swamp and the deeper
down i go the more layers sort of pile
on top of me one guitar on top of
another guitar more vocals more bass the
strings and what's so awesome is that
this record is so freaking loud and yeah
all of these things are balanced really
nicely in the mix later into the song
coma burn you get these double bass
drums and these harsher vocals it's
really a visceral point on this track a
blood pumping point especially with the
tremolo pick guitars on this spot in the
song thunderous riffs come later after
this and the way that some of the chords
resolve that the band is playing here at
the end of the track it almost feels
kind of
uplifting or even positive as varied as
some of these songs are when you listen
to them closely that's one thing that i
wish these tracks had a little bit more
of not only that just positive beauty
but those more just
adrenaline-fed moments most of this
record shoots for an epically dreary
vibe and that's fine because the band
does it incredibly well i just wish
there were more visceral spots because
it definitely would have given this lp a
bit more of a flow because while i do
enjoy the three tracks here a lot i
don't really feel like i'm on a journey
from beginning to end with the album but
for sure each track in itself feels like
a trip even the slower and more
melodically layered track engravings the
second song here even though it is a bit
shorter than the opener and and it
doesn't really have a hard-hitting spot
in its nine-minute run time i think it
may be my favorite track here just
because of how beautiful some of the
guitar phrasing is and the clothes are
on here while it does end with with a
seven minute drone which which i guess
in a sense is giving this album some
kind of closure it is a really hypnotic
spot on the lp and it does kind of
provide some cool down time to make me
feel like okay this is done but i i
wouldn't necessarily say that the song
is is any more epic or climactic than
the two previous tracks i still think
the heavy riffs and a lot of the guitar
phrasing in the middle of the track are
great and i do love the intro which
feels very grails like with its echo
drenched guitars which are just
shimmering and have a bit of a desert
vibe to them i just wish the band did
something a little bit more
radical to it i do think in a sense they
were conscious of the either the
limitations or just the very few
elements that they were working with on
these songs and they didn't want to
overdo it or anything like that and only
offered really just 40 minutes of music
which if you're talking about metal of
the style it's not really like lycus is
asking that much from the listener i
guess aside from the playing and the
melody writing the thing that i can
commend this album for most is taking
these ideas that that would normally
require a listener to be really really
patient and in a way sort of condense
them down into a very succinct funeral
doom metal record i'm feeling a decent
to strong seven on this thing if you've
given it a listen what did you think of
it did you love it hate it why what do
you think i should review next and
that's it this review is my opinion if
you don't like it here's a straw i want
to give a shout out to austin young lean
and melidy's bread only the strong
subscribe all mistakes were intentional
anthony
tempest
like us
forever
[Music]
